Accaus.

The question of accent presents little difficulty as to place, but some as to quality, and much as to kind.

As to quality, it must be remembered that while the acute accent is found on syllables either short or long (by nature or position), and on either the penult or the antepenult, the circumflex is found only on long vowels, and (in words

of more than one syllable) only on the penult, and then only in case the ultima is short. Thus, spes, but dux, lund, but Μυός legdtus, but legdti. In these examples the length ol the syllable is the same and of course remains the same in inflection‚ but the quality of the accent changes. In the one case the voice is both raised and depressed on the same syllable, in the other it is only raised.
